columns.text: In this exercise, we have to determine the effect of the stock split on the equity accounts and the last year's dividend per share.

**Stock Split** is a company action that increases the number of outstanding shares while decreasing the market value of each shares. Although the number of outstanding shares and price per share decreases, the total shareholders' equity does not change.

To begin, let's first compute the new par value per share. Given that the company decides on a four-for-one stock split, we will divide the par value by 4. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{New Par Value} &= \dfrac{\text{Par Value}}{\text{4}}\\[10pt]
&= \dfrac{\text{\$\hspace{5pt}1}}{\text{4}}\\[10pt]
&=\text\$\hspace{5pt}0.25 \text{ per share}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen, the par value decreased from $1 to $0.25.**

Next, we will compute the new shares outstanding after the stock split.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{New Shares Outstanding} 
&= \text{Share Outstanding}\times{\text{Share split}}\\[5pt]
 &= \text{245,000}\times{4}\\[10pt] &=\boxed{\textbf{980,000 shares}}\\ \end{aligned}$$

**As can be seen, the number of shares outstanding increased from 245,000 to 980,000 shares.**

Next, let's compute the total common stock after the stock split by multiplying the new shares outstanding by the new par value.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Common Stock} 
&= \text{Share Outstanding}\times{\text{Par Value}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{980,000}\times{\$ 0.25}\\[5pt] 
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$ 245,000}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

**Therefore, there is no effect of stock on the value of the common stock.**

**The value of the capital surplus and retained earnings will be the same after the stock split.** Additionally, there is no journal entry recorded for a stock split instead, the company prepares a memo entry.

Next, we will compute the last year dividend per share of the company. We will squeeze back the equation. To determine the last year dividend, we will **let x be the last years dividend if split off doesn't take place.**

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{CurrentYear Dividend} &= \text{Last Year Dividend}+{\text{Increase in dividend }}\\[10pt]
\text{\$ 0.65}&= \text{x}+{\text{10\%(x)}}\\[10pt]
\text{\$ 0.65}&= \text{x}+{\text{0.10x
}}\\[10pt]
\text{\$ 0.65}&= \text{1.10x}\\[10pt]
\text{x}&=\dfrac{\text\${0.65}}{1.10}\\[10pt]
&=\boxed{\$\hspace{5pt}0.5909}\\
\end{aligned}$$


As can be seen, the last year dividend if split off doesn't take place is **$0.5909**.

Lastly, we will now determine the last year dividend per share after the stock split.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Last Year Dividend} 
&= \text{Last Year Dividend}\times{\text{4}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{\$ 0.5909}\times{4}\\[5pt] 
&=\boxed{\textbf{\$ 2.36}}\\ 
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the last year dividend per share after the stock split is **$2.36.**
